awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Automated scientific discovery and the philosophical problem of natural kinds
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

This is a Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award, the NSF's most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations. This award supports an integrated research and education project that addresses a fundamental scientific question:  Out of countless number of empirical quantities related to some phenomenon of interest, to which quantities should attention be directed in order to successfully discover the regularities or laws behind the phenomenon? Only a special few facilitate accurate generalization from a few particular facts to a great many that are not in evidence, and yet in the course of their work scientists efficiently choose variables that support generalization. That scientists are able to do this is both fascinating and perplexing. This project will clarify and test a new approach to solving this puzzle by constructing a series of computer algorithms that automatically carry out a process of variable choice in the service of autonomous scientific discovery. The inductive success of these algorithms when applied to genuine problems in current scientific settings will serve as tangible validation of the theory underlying these algorithms. The automated discovery algorithms produced will be leveraged to introduce a generation of graduate students in philosophy and science to the deep connections between physical computing and formal epistemology. A recurring summer school will train graduate students in basic programming and formal methods, with hands on development of automated discovery systems.

Technical Summary 

This project connects the philosophical problem of natural kinds with computational problems of automated discovery in artificial intelligence. It tests a new approach, a dynamical natural kinds theory, denoted the Dynamical Kinds Theory, by deriving discovery algorithms from that theory's normative content and then applying these algorithms to real-world phenomena. The inductive success of these algorithms when applied to genuine problems in current scientific settings will serve as tangible validation of the philosophical theory. More dramatically, these discovery algorithms have the potential to produce more than one equally effective but inconsistent classification of phenomena into kinds. The existence of such alternatives plays a central role in debates over scientific realism. Outside of philosophy, the application of the discovery algorithms to open problems in areas of ecology, evolution, metagenomics, metabolomics, and systems biology has the potential to suggest previously unconceived theories of the fundamental ontology in these fields. In particular, the algorithms will be applied to agent-based models of evolutionary dynamics to search for population-level laws, and to publicly available long-term ecological data to search for stable dynamical kinds outside the standard set of ecological categories.

por.por_cntn:
While philosophers have explored with mathematical precision the logic of many aspects of scientific inference, two central sorts of scientific thought have largely escaped scrutiny. The first puzzle, referred to as the problem of "natural kinds" in philosophical circles, is this: without first knowing the natural laws that govern some class of phenomena how can we tell which phenomena are likely to be governed by the same laws? In other words, which collections of things behave similarly enough that we should expect to find a law that allows us to predict and control their behavior? The second puzzle, long argued to be impossible to solve, is this: how can we systematically infer new variables or previously unconceived properties in terms of which to describe the world? These two problems are intimately related: We introduce novel variables to account for observed variation in behavior within a natural kind. So if we could identify natural kinds, we could spot new variables.  This project set out to test a philosophical account of natural kinds -- the Dynamical Kinds Theory (DKT) -- by putting it to work in genuine scientific contexts, and to demonstrate that such a theory allows for the systematic identification of new scientific variables.

The idea at the core of the DKT is that what unites systems governed by a shared law is that they are indifferent to the same manipulations. For example, all exponentially growing populations are indifferent to manipulations that scale the population in the sense that whether one doubles the yeast cells in a fermentation vat and then lets them grow or first lets them grow and then doubles the population, you end up with the same number of yeast cells. This idea let us construct a proper metric -- a measure of distance -- on the dynamics of systems. This metric not only indicates whether two systems of unknown dynamics belong to the same natural kind but also the extent to which their governing laws differ. The more two systems differ in their degree of nonlinearity, effective order (history dependence), or chaotic behavior, the further apart they are according to this metric. We recognized that a wide range of inferential tasks beyond grouping systems into natural kinds fundamentally involve recognizing the similarity of dynamics, and we built a suite of open source tools in Python called "EUGENE" for putting our metric to work in data-driven clustering, model validation, model behavior mapping, change detection, and the identification of novel scientific variables.

The efficacy of these automated discovery tools was demonstrated in related studies. For instance, collective behavior in animals -- such as the coordinated swarming of midges -- is easy to recognize but difficult to quantify. Using tools in EUGENE, we demonstrated that our dynamical distance metric allows for the robust classification of swarming behavior under different environmental conditions using only the information that can be gleaned from ordinary two-dimensional video. Of greatest philosophical relevance was a set of experiments involving the flow of water through different granular materials. Not only was it demonstrated that the proposed method of variable discovery does in fact identify new variables useful for further description of scientific laws, but that successive generations of discovered variables looked increasingly less familiar relative to existing theories of fluid flow. This suggests that it may in fact be possible to produce more than one equally effective but inconsistent set of variables, laws, and corresponding natural kinds. The existence of such alternatives plays a central role in debates over scientific realism.

Playing a central role throughout this project was a training program designed to equip the next generation of scientists and philosophers with the interdisciplinary skills to deploy, refine, and expand philosophically motivated discovery methods. For each of four years, a new group of participants from philosophy, computer science, and the empirical sciences gathered from around the world for a two-week summer school in which they learned programming skills, hardware interfacing, formal epistemology, the philosophy of science, machine learning, statistical learning theory, and formal learning theory. These summer sessions, which ultimately trained some 54 graduate students and early career faculty, culminated in pedagogical training and a two-day outreach event for early secondary school students called "The Robot Scientist". In these latter events, we helped 116 children develop an understanding of the logic of discovery by writing simple programs to sense and manipulate the world, operating robots to solve tasks, and solving causal learning problems with physical devices. Importantly, these children --- most of whom hailed from some of the districts in Virginia with the highest rates of child poverty --- got to take home the Raspberry Pi computer systems they had trained on, providing not just a platform for further experimentation and exploration, but a general purpose home computer for future school and professional use.
